case_name: Workmen of Messrs Hindustan Motors Ltd. v. Hindustan Motors Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 635 of 1965 filed by workmen of Hindustan Motors Ltd. against decision of First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 635 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated January 8. 1963 of the First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIH-354 of 1961.

facts.text: Award dated January 8, 1963 by First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIH-354 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated January 8. 1963 of the First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIH-354 of 1961.

facts.text: Dispute relates to payment of bonus for the year 1960-61.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave has been filed by the workmen of Messrs Hindustan Motors Ltd. against the decision of the First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in a dispute relating to payment of bonus for the year 1960-61.

facts.text: Hindustan Motors Ltd. established in 1942, initially assembling motor cars from imported components.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, M s Hindustan Motors Ltd.,  hereinafter referred to as the Company  was established in the year 1942 and, initially, the work taken up by the Company was that of assembling of motor cars from companyponents imported from foreign companyntries.

facts.text: Company started manufacturing components of motor cars in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Later on, manufacture of companyponents of motor cars was started and gradually the Company developed this work of manufacture of companyponents by increasing the number of companyponents manufactured by it until, at the present time, the Company is manufacturing more than 70 of the companyponents utilised in the cars put on the market by the Company. The work of manufacturing companyponents was taken in hand for the first time in the year 1949,

facts.text: In 1960-61, Company showed net profit of Rs. 249.71 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: In this year 1960-61, the profit and loss account of the Company showed a net profit of Rs. 249.71 lacs.

facts.text: Dividend allocated: Rs. 59.53 lacs on ordinary shares, Rs. 27.55 lacs on preference shares, total Rs. 87.08 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this, a sum of Rs. 59.53 lacs was allocated for payment of dividend on ordinary shares 12 and a sum of Rs. 27.55 lacs for dividend on preference shares 8.57. The total amount allocated for payment of dividends was thus Rs. 87.08 lacs.

facts.text: Workmen demanded bonus equivalent to six months wages, total Rs. 24 lacs (net about 55% after tax refund).

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that, in this year, the Company had earned a net profit of over Rs. 249 lacs. the workmen demanded bonus equivalent to six months wages. The monthly wage bill of the workmen is about Rs. 4 lacs, so that the total amount claimed towards bonus by the workmen came to Rs. 24 lacs.

facts.text: Tribunal arrived at surplus of Rs. 87.80 lacs without rehabilitation, but held Rs. 373.62 lacs needed for rehabilitation, so no bonus payable.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, after making all other deductions from the surplus which have to be made in accordance with the Full Bench Formula and without taking into account provision for rehabilitation, arrived at a figure of Rs. 87.80 lacs as the amount of surplus available. Thereafter, the Tribunal held that a sum of Rs. 373.62 lacs every year was needed for rehabilitation purposes

facts.text: No dispute that Full Bench Formula from Associated Cement Companies case applies.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal, there was numberdispute between the parties that, in order to find out whether any surplus was available for distribution of bonus, calculations must be made on the basis of the Full Bench Formula approved by this Court in The Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Dwarka Cement Works, Dwarka v. Its Workmen Another 1 .

facts.text: Company filed reply on 10th January 1962 stating manufacturing started in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The work of manufacturing companyponents was taken in hand for the first time in the year 1949, according to the reply of the Company filed on 10th January, 1962, to the statement filed on behalf of the workmen. before the Tribunal.

facts.text: Company ran at loss until late 1956, Tariff Commission reported loss of Rs. 833 per car on Hindustan Landmaster.

anchor.surface_text: At the initial stages of its existence, the Company was running at a loss and even, as late as the year 1956. the Tariff Commissions Report on the Automobile Industry mentioned that this Company was making a loss of Rs. 833 per car on the Hindustan Landmaster which was the car put on the market by the Company at that time.

facts.text: Dispute for 1959-60 bonus still pending before Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We were informed that the dispute relating to the payment of bonus for the year l 959-60 is still pending before the Industrial Tribunal, while the dispute with respect to bonus for the next year 1960-61 has been decided and is number before us in this appeal.

facts.text: Company claimed average total life of machinery 6 years in first Schedule IA filed 31st May 1962.

anchor.surface_text: When the dispute was taken up for adjudication by the Tribunal, the Company, on 3 l st May, 1962 filed statements showing calculations of rehabilitation provision required for rehabilitating the plant, machinery and buildings. Amongst these statements was a statement described as Schedule IA  hereinafter referred to as the first Schedule IA  and in that statement it was claimed on behalf of the Company that the average total life of its machinery was 6 years.

facts.text: Workmen claimed life of machinery 30 years.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the workmen, it was urged that the life of the machinery should be taken to be 30 years and on this basis, ,after the arguments were over a rehabilitation companyt calculation was filed on 21st November, 1962.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds average useful life of machinery 15 years on two shifts basis.

anchor.surface_text: After tak-  1  1962 2 supp. S.C.R. 926. ing into companysideration the various factors mentioned by us above, and on the evidence before us, we think that in this case, it would. be appropriate to hold that the average life of the machinery of this. Company in respect of different kinds of machines obtained from different sources may be appropriately taken as 15 years.

facts.text: Machines worked in two shifts until 1959-60, then three shifts.

anchor.surface_text: Girish Chandra Bansal, one of the Engineers of the Company, examined as a witness, stated that the machines in this Company were working in two shifts only, until, for the first time in 1959-60, the factory started to run round-the- clock, i.e., in three shifts.

facts.text: Depreciation provided Rs. 325.48 lacs at beginning of 1960-61.

anchor.surface_text: The annual report of this Company for the year of bonus 1960-61 was produced before us and at page 24 it showed that at the beginning of the year 1960-61 depreciation to the extent of Rs. 325.48 lacs had been provided in the balance- sheet of the Company.

facts.text: Development rebate reserve Rs. 39.51 lacs on 31-3-1960, treated as available liquid reserve.

anchor.surface_text: There. was a reserve for companytingencies to the extent of Rs. 10.00 lacs on 31-3-1960 and a development rebate reserve of Rs. 39.51 lacs on the same date.

facts.text: Fixed deposits Rs. 220 lacs shown in balance-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: From the balance-sheet itself an inference was sought to be drawn that this reserve existed in the form of a liquid reserve available for rehabilitation. For this purpose reference was made to the entries on the assets side of the balance-sheet which shows a sum of Rs. 220 lacs as lying in fixed deposit account.

facts.text: Company claimed all reserves used as working capital per affidavit of Satya Narayan Murarka.

anchor.surface_text: In this affidavit, Murarka stated. that all the sums shown as reserves and surpluses in the balance-sheet were available for being utilised as working capital and were, in  fact, so utilised.

facts.text: Tribunal classified machinery into precision and non-precision based on Income-tax depreciation rates.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the Tribunal, in making this direction was also influenced by the circumstance that, under the Income-tax Law, the depreciation allowed in respect of precision and number-precision machinery is different, from which the Tribunal. inferred that precision machinery will have a shorter life than number-precision machinery.

facts.text: Both parties challenge Tribunal's classification of machinery into precision and non-precision.

anchor.surface_text: Since both parties before us challenge the adoption of this classification by the Tribunal, we companysider that it will be right to ignore this. classification and to proceed on the basis that the total life of the machinery must be worked out on an average for all the machines installed in the factory of the Company

facts.text: Expert Gerald Waplington testified economic life 2-6 years, useful life 6-18 years (1/3 economic).

anchor.surface_text: In giving the life of machinery, Waplington first classified the machines into two classes--general purpose machine tools and special or single purpose machine tools--and expressed the opinion that a general purpose machine tool used for one single operation is likely to have a shorter economic life than special or single purpose machine tool.

facts.text: Company engineers Joyce and Bansal estimated economic life 6-10 years on 16 hours/day.

anchor.surface_text: According to Joyce, the economic life of the machinery of the Company cannot go beyond 6 years, and this statement was. made on the basis of the machines working 16 hours a. day in two shifts of 8 hours each.
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated January 8. 1963 of the First Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIH-354 of 1961.

Before the Tribunal, there was numberdispute between the parties that, in order to find out whether any surplus was available for distribution of bonus, calculations must be made on the basis of the Full Bench Formula approved by this Court in The Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Dwarka Cement Works, Dwarka v. Its Workmen Another 1 .

concepts.interpretation: Calculations for surplus available for bonus must follow this formula, including deductions for rehabilitation, return on capital, depreciation; court corrects Tribunal's application on rehabilitation components.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal committed an error in applying the Full Bench Formula in respect of rehabilitation, return on reserves used as working capital, return on paid-up capital, interest on fixed deposits, and home delivery commission.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the workmen, however, it was urged that the Tribunal committed an error in applying the Formula in respect of five different items involved in the calculation. These are Rehabilitation, Return on reserves used as working capital, Return on paid-up capital, Interest on fixed deposits, and Home delivery commission.

issues.text: What is the correct divisor for rehabilitation, depending on the life of plant, machinery and buildings, year of installation, and residuary life.

anchor.surface_text: The factors in calculation of rehabilitation accepted by the Tribunal which have been challenged by the workmen are the divisor, which depends upon the life of the plant, machinery and buildings, the year of their installation or erection, and the residuary life which must be taken into account when working out the divisor,

issues.text: Whether machinery should be classified into precision and non-precision for different lives in rehabilitation calculation.

anchor.surface_text: In the course of arguments before us, it was urged on behalf of the workmen that the Company not having claimed that machinery classified as precision had a shorter life than machinery classified as non-precision

issues.text: Whether the useful life of machinery should be based on income-tax depreciation rates.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, in its decision, worked out the life of the machinery on the basis of the percentage of depreciation allowed under the Income-tax Act. The application of this principle has been attacked before us by both the parties.

issues.text: What is the average useful life of the company's machinery for rehabilitation purposes.

anchor.surface_text: After taking into consideration the various factors mentioned by us above, and on the evidence before us, we think that in this case, it would be appropriate to hold that the average life of the machinery of this Company

issues.text: Which multipliers to use for replacement cost in rehabilitation: first Schedule IA, average, or reduced for productivity.

anchor.surface_text: The second factor entering the calculation of rehabilitation requirement about which there was controversy between the parties is the multiplier. We have already mentioned the fact that, in the first and the third Schedules 1A,

issues.answer: first Schedule IA without averaging or reduction

issues.text: Whether development rebate reserve is a liquid reserve to deduct in rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: There was a reserve for contingencies to the extent of Rs. 10.00 lacs on 31-3-1960 and a development rebate reserve of Rs. 39.51 lacs on the same date.

issues.text: Whether depreciation and liquid reserves should be deducted from total rehabilitation or from earliest blocks first.

anchor.surface_text: The last controversy in the calculations for rehabilitation provision is on the question whether the depreciation and the liquid reserves available should be deducted from the total amount of rehabilitation requirement

issues.text: Whether affidavit evidence suffices to prove reserves used as working capital for return allowance.

arguments.claim: Rehabilitation covers replacement, modernisation, not just pure replacement or expansion.

anchor.surface_text: In the latter case, this Court, when examining the scope of claim for rehabilitation held that this claim covers not only cases of replacement pure and Simple but of rehabilitation and modernisation.

arguments.claim: Deduct depreciation and liquid reserves from earliest rehabilitation blocks first.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the workmen, we think, it was rightly urged that, if depreciation and liquid reserves available are to be deducted, they must be incorporated in the accounts against the replacement cost of those items which required replacement earliest in time.

arguments.court_reasoning: Logical and as in Associated Cement; prevents delaying replacement.

holdings.text: Ignore the Tribunal's classification of machinery into precision and non-precision; proceed on average total life for all machines.

anchor.surface_text: Since both parties before us challenge the adoption of this classification by the Tribunal, we consider that it will be right to ignore this classification and to proceed on the basis that the total life of the machinery must be worked out on an average for all the machines installed in the factory of the Company

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both parties challenge classification; no party claimed it; IT depreciation not basis for life.

holdings.text: Life of machinery cannot be determined on basis of Income-tax Act depreciation percentages; must be based on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, in its decision, worked out the life of the machinery on the basis of the percentage of depreciation allowed under the Income-tax Act. The application of this principle has been attacked before us by both the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Artificial rule; parties agree erroneous; follow precedent requiring evidence on factory-specific factors.

holdings.text: Average useful life of machinery is 15 years on two-shift basis (25 years one shift, 10 years three shifts); include bonus-year machinery.

anchor.surface_text: After taking into consideration the various factors mentioned by us above, and on the evidence before us, we think that in this case, it would be appropriate to hold that the average life of the machinery of this Company in respect of different kinds of machines obtained from different sources may be appropriately taken as 15 years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balance expert evidence, company history, usage shifts, discards; reject economic life/American standards.

holdings.text: Use multipliers only from first Schedule IA; no averaging with second/third; no reduction for assumed higher productivity.

anchor.surface_text: The second factor entering the calculation of rehabilitation requirement about which there was controversy between the parties is the multiplier. We have already mentioned the fact that, in the first and the third Schedules 1A

holdings.reasoning_summary: First proved by comparable purchases Ext.29; second unproved post-evidence; no evidence of capacity increase warranting apportionment.

holdings.text: Deduct depreciation from replacement cost regardless of current liquidity/availability.

anchor.surface_text: The annual report of this Company for the year of bonus 1960-61 was produced before us and at page 24 it showed that at the beginning of the year 1960-61 depreciation to the extent of Rs. 325.48 lacs had been provided

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rehab covers gap after depreciation recoup; 'available' qualifies reserves only; deduct Rs.325.48 lacs.

holdings.text: Development rebate reserve (Rs.39.51 lacs) and contingencies reserve (Rs.10 lacs) are general liquid reserves deductible.

anchor.surface_text: There was a reserve for contingencies to the extent of Rs. 10.00 lacs on 31-3-1960 and a development rebate reserve of Rs. 39.51 lacs on the same date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balance-sheet shows liquidity (fixed deposits Rs.220 lacs); mere affidavit insufficient contra.

holdings.text: Deduct depreciation and liquid reserves from earliest rehabilitation blocks first, not pro rata from total.

anchor.surface_text: The last controversy in the calculations for rehabilitation provision is on the question whether the depreciation and the liquid reserves available should be deducted from the total amount of rehabilitation requirement

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical: use available funds for immediate needs; prevents delaying replacement; follows Associated Cement calc.

holdings.text: Mere affidavit insufficient to prove all reserves/surpluses used as working capital, given liquidity evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In this affidavit, Murarka stated that all the sums shown as reserves and surpluses in the balance-sheet were available for being utilised as working capital and were, in fact, so utilised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fixed deposits indicate liquidity; cross-exam opportunity unused but affidavit bare; distinguish prior cases.

holdings.text: Tribunal erred in rehabilitation calculation; correct method yields surplus for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the workmen, however, it was urged that the Tribunal committed an error in applying the Formula in respect of five different items involved in the calculation. These are Rehabilitation, Return on reserves used as working capital

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corrected errors on divisor/multiplier/deductions lead to surplus after prior charges.

holdings.text: Life of factory/non-factory buildings as per Tribunal (25/40 years); no reliable evidence to vary.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the workmen with regard to buildings was that the Tribunal, in taking the life of the factory buildings at 25 years and non-factory buildings at 40 years, was not correct

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reliable evidence from either side; IT rule not dispositive; no analogy to precedents.

holdings.text: Full Bench Formula applies to determine available surplus for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal, there was no dispute between the parties that, in order to find out whether any surplus was available for distribution of bonus, calculations must be made on the basis of the Full Bench Formula

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties agree; approved in Associated Cement.

holdings.text: Rehabilitation covers replacement, modernisation (not expansion); evidence-based.

anchor.surface_text: In the latter case, this Court, when examining the scope of claim for rehabilitation held that this claim covers not only cases of replacement pure and Simple but of rehabilitation and modernisation.
